Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: SDNatics: Big Data Analytics of Software Defined Networks to Understand, Predict and Protect Critical Computer Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Conventional computer network management has serious limitations on granularity, responsiveness and predictability, which can lead to network failures costing millions of dollars in critical domains, e.g., public safety and health care. Today's networks are currently managed under various enterprise policies and with state-of-the-art tools such as software defined networking (SDN) controllers. However, the faults and problems in the networks still arise because there are always cases to which predefined rules and algorithms do not respond well, causing traffic flooding, congestions, or vulnerability to attacks. Understanding in-depth of the network behavior patterns and applying the knowledge in network management and planning are fundamental to providing new solutions and best practices.

This team has developed a suite of protocols and analytics methods to understand network dynamics by using software-defined networking (SDN) and machine learning technologies. With this information the team is able to report abnormal network behavior and alert potential faults. This allows for much more of the network to be managed algorithmically, automatically, and intelligently. Specifically, this team's technology is able to track network flows to a much higher granularity (i.e. resolution) using SDN technology. However, while current SDN approaches are better than traditional networks in defining and enforcing rules around network flows, they do not have a capability to analyze in-depth usage behavior and dynamically apply such information to improve network management and planning. By using machine learning techniques (i.e. Deep Learning), the team will develop the SDNatics software platform that will allow for more advance uses of SDN. Such improvements should improve security, predictability, speed, and data volume in network systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF I-Corps project provided a life-changing educational experience for the project team on exploring the process of technology transfer and commercialization. The project had three members on the team: Entrepreneur Lead - Peilong Li, Principal Investigator - Yan Luo, and Business Mentor - Ray Southworth. All team members worked together to interview 100 potential customers during the six weeks and revised our business canvas by applying “hypothesize-experiment-validate” strategy with the inputs from I-Corps instructors. The team spent more than 30 hours a week to read curriculum materials, watch instruction videos, conduct the interviews and finish the assignments. The team had gone through a very intense and vigirous interviewing-discussion-analysis procedure, and the business ideas were getting close to cogency after each experiment.

 

During the learning process, the team negated most ideas on the initial business canvas proposal and pivoted twice to find a critical potential customer - healthcare and two important business values - 1) providing actionable intelligence of the network to corporate ITs; and 2) securing non-patchable medical devices on a network with low cost. After spending three weeks attending the potential competitors conferences and road shows, the team realized there were still three critical obstacles ahead of us. Firstly, the market competition was intense and there was not a 100% differentiator from the competitors. Secondly, decision makers of a corporate typically spending 12 times more budget on recruiting network management and security talents than purchasing software. Thirdly, more than 80% of the computer network faults came from mis-operations from the network users, however,  the proposed technology cannot help educate network end users.

 

Therefore, the team finally reached the decision that the focused technology of its existing stand was a “NO GO”. However, the team planed to investigate the related topics and markets in the near future to find the best fit technology and market fit. The team would also like to conduct healthcare related interviews more aggressively since healthcare seemed to be a missing piece now in the network management area.

 

In summary, the outcomes of this project include a more clear understanding of the market needs and competitors, a good understanding of the technology transfer and commercialization methodology, and the engagement to a community of university researchers and business development mentors.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2015
Modified by: Yan Luo
